question.title: Could this (unsafe) code crash the JVM?

node.contents: No. It will always throw NullPointerException earlier, at `unsafe = (Unsafe) f.get(null);`

astNode.text: No. It will always throw NullPointerException earlier, at `unsafe = (Unsafe) f.get(null);`

node.contents: @ElliottFrisch: Why? ["If the underlying field is a static field, the obj argument is ignored; it may be null."](http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/reflect/Field.html#get(java.lang.Object))

astNode.text: @ElliottFrisch: Why? ["If the underlying field is a static field, the obj argument is ignored; it may be null."](http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/reflect/Field.html#get(java.lang.Object))

node.contents: @ElliottFrisch, no it won't. This is a normal, I'd say canonical, way of getting a static field of a class. If theUnsafe was an instance variable, you'd be right, though.

astNode.text: @ElliottFrisch, no it won't. This is a normal, I'd say canonical, way of getting a static field of a class. If theUnsafe was an instance variable, you'd be right, though.

node.contents: Sorry, I just looked again. I thought OP was accessing `unsafe` in `K`, not the field here [`Unsafe`](http://www.docjar.com/html/api/sun/misc/Unsafe.java.html).

astNode.text: Sorry, I just looked again. I thought OP was accessing `unsafe` in `K`, not the field here [`Unsafe`](http://www.docjar.com/html/api/sun/misc/Unsafe.java.html).

node.contents: In this particular case, the Integer object (created by autoboxing) won't be garbage collected, because Integer keeps a reference to it in a static array.

astNode.text: In this particular case, the Integer object (created by autoboxing) won't be garbage collected, because Integer keeps a reference to it in a static array.

elements.contents: import sun.misc.Unsafe; import java.lang.reflect.*; public class K { private static Unsafe unsafe; private static int fieldOffset; private static K instance = new K(); static { try { Field f = Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); f.setAccessible(true); unsafe = (Unsafe) f.get(null); fieldOffset = unsafe.fieldOffset(K.class.getDeclaredField("obj")); } catch (Exception ex) { throw new RuntimeException(ex); } } private Object obj; public synchronized static long toAddress(int o) { instance.obj = o; return unsafe.getLong(instance, fieldOffset); } public synchronized static Object toObject(long address) { unsafe.putLong(instance, fieldOffset, address); return instance.obj; } public static void main(String[] args) { int x = 20; System.err.println("x was = " + x); long addr = toAddress(x); System.err.println("&x = " + addr); x = 70; System.out.println("x is now " + x); long newAddr = toAddress(x); System.err.println("new (&x) = " + newAddr); System.out.println("Previous value of x is " + toObject(addr)); // !!! } }

node.contents: In particular, I'm worried about the line marked with !!!. If the original x gets garbage collected then its address will presumably be worthless.

astNode.text: In particular, I'm worried about the line marked with !!!. If the original x gets garbage collected then its address will presumably be worthless.

node.contents: My question is will the JVM segfault or will toObject(BOGUS_VALUE) always fail with a NullPointerException (which can be caught)?

astNode.text: My question is will the JVM segfault or will toObject(BOGUS_VALUE) always fail with a NullPointerException (which can be caught)?

node.contents: As I'm sure most of you know, the Unsafe documentaton is spotty at best.

astNode.text: As I'm sure most of you know, the Unsafe documentaton is spotty at best.

node.contents: I tried doing something similar but my GC wasn't kicking in. Looks like you were (un)luckier :) Thanks!

astNode.text: I tried doing something similar but my GC wasn't kicking in. Looks like you were (un)luckier :) Thanks!

node.contents: I added some code that would potentially cause a GC before trying to retrieve the lost object.

astNode.text: I added some code that would potentially cause a GC before trying to retrieve the lost object.

elements.contents: for (int i = 0; i < 1000000; i ++) { new Object().toString(); } System.out.println("Previous value of x is " + toObject(addr).getClass()); // !!!

units.rawText: for (int i = 0; i < 1000000; i ++) { new Object().toString(); } Systemoutprintln("Previous value of x is "+ toObject(addr).getClass()); // !!!

node.contents: The address you have probably no longer points to something that could be considered an object. It is Unsafe.

astNode.text: The address you have probably no longer points to something that could be considered an object. It is Unsafe.
